body.p:
Virginia City Nevada Teritory
October 29th 1862
Hon. J. J. Crittenden.
Dr. Sir.

Mr. Wm A. M. Van Bokkelen of this City, wishes to procure the appointment of the Governor of Ky. of Commissioner of Deeds of that State for this Territory. There are many Kentuckians here whose convenience will be promoted by having a resident Comr here, and we can recommend Mr. VanB. as entirely worthy and well qualified for the position, His appointment will give us great pleasure. Although you are taking no active part in political affairs now, yet I have thought you would in this matter oblige old constituents and friends by endorsing Mr VanBs application to the Gov. of Ky. which will doubtless be sufficient to secure the appointment.

Even in this accidental
communication I cannot forbear the opportunity to thank you for former kindness to me. Your appointment of me as one of your aids when Govr of Ky was my first political promotion, and your letters of introduction when I came to California in 1850 contributed materially to my welfare. Allow me also to express my regret that the evening of your life, which has been so nobly spent in the service of your Country, should be rendered unhappy by its misery and peril, which you are compelled sorrowfully to witness, after having vainly endeavored to prevent -- from fields of blood and tears good men now look back to the "Crittenden Compromise" as the tired swimmer looks to the fading shore when he is drifting seaward.

With unabated respect and affection for our old Ky. Chief I remain
Your Obliged friend
Theodore Miller
